text: hi everyone slapped a nice Latino here
the Internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new rowdy
rich album please excuse me for being
antisocial this is the debut album of
compton singer-songwriter rapper mr.
rowdy rich a record that came out at the
very end of last year in december it
fell through the cracks for me a little
bit as the end of my year was focused on
catching up with some records i was
looking at for a good part of the year
also list week but ferati this actually
ended up being a perfect time to drop
this album with little competition and
lots of streams the record shot right up
to number one on the Billboard charts
and then returned to that spot again a
few weeks later which was due in part to
the album's last single the box
snowballing into the number one song in
the country so this thing miraculously
turned out to be a last minute stunner
during a time in the industry where most
of the focus is on end of your coverage
Grammy season around the corner I also
didn't go into this thing expecting a
whole lot considering how
middle-of-the-road rotties performances
were in the ciphers and the free styles
from this past double XL freshman class
and I will admit on the surface and in
concept this record might not seem like
much Roddy is essentially another auto
crooner a disciple of young thug and
future both of whom he borrows some
inflections from pretty heavily across
this record so you could say he's one
more drop in the bucket of countless
rappers competing in the same exact Lane
sure but he is actually pulling into the
lead here and doing it by bringing more
focus and talent to the table for one it
is refreshing to hear a record in this
style with a series of songs that don't
just sound like streaming fodder don't
just sound like wash rinse repeat don't
just sound like you spent maybe 20
minutes on each of these tracks which
not only shows in so many of the courses
on this thing being so damn sharp but
also in the storytelling in the more
introspective musings you might catch on
a track like prayers to the trap God or
the mega cinematic closer war baby which
beautifully and tragically tops the
record off with these amazing string
sections choral vocals a lot of the same
somatic while
these carry over onto the intro cut here
to the glamorous pianos the airy synth
strings all of the lyrics referencing
these traumatic brushes with death
permit the scene in his eyes crying
purple tears and once the beat drops
yeah but it's really Roddy's expressive
and dynamic voice that makes this track
and so many others here too the flow on
this track is solid he is constantly
making little melodic embellishments to
it as well as the song progresses his
range is pretty good and the auto-tune
proves to be more of an effect than it
is a crutch which is especially true of
the Box the number one single I
mentioned earlier where rowdy gives a
particularly elastic vocal performance
for the whole damn seal I'm gonna get
lazy which is just one of maybe half a
dozen super sticky vocal lines all over
this track it's one thing to have a
unique or a good voice and hop on any
instrumental and just riff and maybe
some good ideas come out in the process
and then it's another thing to have a
great voice and boil your best ideas
down into a clear and a sharp song which
is what Roddy is doing there's also that
unique little sample the instrumental
that so many people who are fans of the
track have pointed out which I
understand is a just a recording of
Roddy's voice repeated over and over and
over and it's this small funny thing but
ends up adding so much to the track and
it's very stern string samples its
dreary synthesizers the ending of this
album and the start of it are both
relatively strong it's the middle that
is a little hit or miss and when I say
hit or miss I mean there are some tracks
that are just so-so in comparison with
others
there's nothing truly terrible in the
tracklist here in my opinion there are
just songs on this thing where Roddy's
derivative style combined with a lack of
topical inspiration it catches up with
him and makes him sound more average
than I know he is like the track boom
boom boom which honestly sounds like a
leftover from futures Hendrix record a
few years ago there's also the very
ritzy and piano bass
God's eyes which does sound pretty for
the moment that it lasts but its brevity
makes it one of the most underwritten
songs here not one of these strongest
choruses either
I love a lot of the vocal lines on big
step but in comparison with every other
instrumental on the album it gets pretty
stale pretty fast this little guitar
line that is playing over and over and
over really needs something some kind of
change some kind of extension and
addition it's just not broken up enough
the track high-fashion is essentially a
love song about spoiling your
significant other with designer clothes
there are lots of references and
connections from the quality of the
relationship to different designers kind
of a dynamic that's been explored before
and I don't think Roddy is the wittiest
to ever do it I put ice on you because
you've got a cold heart
okay the mustard beat is not bad though
really when this record is at its best
is when Roddy is hitting these amazing
vocal lines against an inspired be like
on perfect time peanut butter seeds came
perfect time I love that one I love the
way that that transitions away from
these future esque muttered internal
monologues on the versus the wild
escalations into his upper register
which is a very young thug esque in this
respect Roddy is a bit of a vocal
chameleon I just wish he spent that
talent chasing after sounds or
inflections that were a bit more
original to him there's also the very
slick moonwalking where Roddy gets
raunchy along with an x-rated verse from
Little Dirk we get a very sensual beat
on this one and one braggadocious or
erotic bar after another the features
generally on this LP I think are so so
we have ty dolla sign here who I think
plays it pretty safe but he does
admittedly fit really nicely into the
track that he's on which is essentially
about having sex in a car and sounds way
more romantic than it should a boogies
performance on this thing is way too
short to even make a dent honestly and
even though gonna doesn't ruin the song
start with me which is I mean more than
enough he melts so deviously into the
song you might not notice he's there if
you're not paying attention
the best feature easily on this thing is
Meek Mill on PETA got got a hold back
that that vegan anger on the fur related
bars but still it's a great hook and in
meek Andrade undoubtedly have chemistry
the funny little woodwind melody worked
into the B is pretty fantastic adds a
lot of character and even though the
song may not be as dramatic or as
introspective as some of the other ones
here that I think are the best it's
still a solid banger overall I like this
LP while Roddy is not the most unique
artist out there right now he is a
talented vocalist and performer and
there is a lot of potential in what he's
doing - it's excellent when he's able to
plug into a more reflective place and
deliver these ODEs to fame XS tough
upbringing drug dealing while Roddy is
most likely going to continue doing
whatever is going to generate a hit as
long as he continues to come from a
personal place I think there's going to
be reason to pay attention to what he
does
hopefully we also see him last long
enough to forge his own style as well
